awd_titl_txt: Ultra-Wide Bandwidth and High Resolution Photonic Analog to Digital and Digital to Analog Converters
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Ultra-Wide Bandwidth and High Resolution Photonic Analog to Digital and Digital to Analog Converters

Abstract:
Nontechnical: In today's technology driven world digital electronics and digital systems are ubiquitous. Their hardware and software are the essence of everything that touches our lives many times a day. Real life systems generate analog signals which need to be converted into digital form before they can be handled by digital technology. This is done using an Analog to Digital Converter (ADC). Almost all the existing ADCs are electronic. There are many types of ADCs with different resolution and speed. As the resolution of an ADC increases its fidelity improves significantly. Although electronic ADCs provide very high resolution they do not operate very fast. This proposal aims to develop a high speed ADC photonics technology which operates without sacrificing resolution. The same technology is used in fiber optic communication systems, is well understood and its parts are commercially available. However, a few special components need to be developed before the entire ADC can be demonstrated. This project will develop and fabricate such components and demonstrate a proof of concept operation of the ADC. Such high resolution and fast ADC will improve many applications, such as instrumentation, radar, optical fiber communication and wide bandwidth signal distribution. 

Technical: This proposal introduces a new and novel approach for a photonic ADC that can deliver eight bits of resolution at bandwidths of 20 GHz and higher. The proposed basic ADC resembles very much to a wavelength division multiplexed (WDM) fiber optic digital link without the fiber. It consists of a multi wavelength source, a quantizer, a sampler, a demultiplexer and receivers. The quantizer is a high-speed Mach-Zehnder modulator (MZM) with an intentional path length difference between its arms. The sampling is done after the quantizer. The sampled outputs at different wavelengths generate a code corresponding to the digitized version of the analog signal applied to the quantizer. This basic idea is improved upon using a subranging approach to improve the number of bits while reducing the component count. This requires a digital to analog converter (DAC), which can be made out of a single MZM. The practical operation of such an ADC requires low-voltage and high-speed MZM for quantizer and DAC. The required ultra-low jitter sampling can also be performed using such MZMs.  The focus of this proposal is to develop these critical components, namely the quantizer, DAC and the sampler, and make a proof of concept demonstration of a scaled down version of the ADC.

por.por_cntn:
In today's technology driven world digital electronics and digital systems are ubiquitous.  Their hardware and software are the essence of everything that touches our lives many times a day.  Real life systems utilizing digital technology need conversion of analog signals into digital form.  This is done using an Analog to Digital Converter (ADC).  There are many types of ADCs with different resolution, bandwidth or sampling rates.  Almost all the existing ADCs are electronic.  The bandwidth and resolution of electronic ADCs are not sufficient for high end applications. Some of these applications are fiber optic communications, high speed instrumentation and radar. 

            This proposal introduces a new and novel approach for a photonic ADC that can deliver high resolution approaching eight bits at bandwidths of 20 GHz and higher. The proposed basic ADC resembles very much to a commercially existing fiber optic digital link without the fiber. The major difference is in the optical modulator that converts an electrical signal into an optical signal. It is an unbalanced Mach Zehnder Modulator (UMZM). This is the quantizer of the ADC and can operate beyond 40 GHz. Quantization is done by feeding several laser outputs at different wavelengths into this quantizer. Signal to be digitized is applied to the modulator electrode. These different wavelengths modulated to different degrees by the analog signal are separated at the output using commercial filters or wavelength demultiplexers. The outputs at different wavelengths are sampled and detected using the same detection threshold and the digital outputs of the receivers generate a code corresponding to the digitized version of the analog signal applied to the quantizer. Most of the parts of this system are well known and commercially available. However, practical operation requires a quantizer or a low-voltage and high-speed MZM that can transmit high optical power levels. In addition, a Digital to Analog Converter is also needed to convert the digital version of the signal back to analog form and also to improve the resolution of the ADC. This can also be realized using a slightly modified version of a regular MZM. The focus of this proposal is to develop these critical components, namely the quantizer and DAC.

            We fabricated such components using GaAs/AlGaAs layers grown on both GaAs and Si substrates. Our material and optical waveguide is designed such that low drive voltage (< 1 V) with bandwidth in excess of 40 GHz are achieved. Furthermore, modulator behavior remained unchanged up to 160 mW of optical power coupled into the input waveguide. This work also resulted in first ever demonstration of such MZMs in GaAs/AlGaAs layers directly grown on Si. This approach presents a huge cost reduction due to availability of very big Si substrates, which is lacking in compound semiconductor materials. Furthermore, most electronics is fabricated in Si. Hence photonic and electronic integration becomes possible. We also developed novel wide bandwidth version of such modulators on Si substrates. This is challenging due to conducting nature of Si substrates. Another major achievement was the elimination or significant reduction of the fiber coupling loss of these devices. Optical waveguides are much smaller than the optical fiber and significant amount of light can be lost when light comes in from a fiber and needs to be coupled into the device and vice versa. The improvement of this situation needs mode transformers. We developed mode transformers based on composite optical dielectric waveguides. It is possible to make big size and small size optical modes in such waveguide by removing certain layers using microfabrication techniques. In this approach all processing is done in dielectric material and expensive and material specific compound semiconductor processing is not needed. Furthermore, compound semiconductors can be used only in the active sections of the device, which eliminates the excess optical loss associated with doping and different material compositions within the compound semiconductor waveguide. This is a significant advantage in achieving full photonic integration, especially on a much bigger and cheaper Si substrate. We also worked on the photonic DAC that decodes digital code of the ADC. The inherent nonlinearity of the MZM modulator was taken out using an algorithm that modifies the lengths of electrode sections on the modulator arms. This allows a very linear operation or eliminates the distortion on the analog signal.

            The results generated in this project has significant potential impact in the field of integrated photonics and its applications. Photonic integrated circuits are used in many different applications such as high-speed communications, instrumentation, health care, Lidar for autonomous driving, ... etc. For example, very low drive voltage, wide bandwidth and high optical power handling modulators developed in this project enable wide bandwidth, light weight photonic links with gain and low noise figure. Linearized DAC designs developed can provide simple and cost-effective arbitrary waveform generators. Hence, they can have significant potential impact in instrumentation.
